title: Colliding blocks and different initial speeds

content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment, in which the following events occur. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A slides to the right along a horizontal surface toward identical block B, which is at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides elastically with block B and block A comes to rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of block B reaches an ideal, horizontal spring with negligible mass and spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spring is initially at its relaxed (uncompressed) length and fixed to a wall. At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the spring is compressed a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and block B is instantaneously at rest. Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface. For parts (a)-(d), consider the system consisting of block A, block B, and the spring. (a) Indicate whether the linear momentum of the two-block–spring system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to immediately before <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) The figure above shows Case 1 of an experiment, in which the following events occur. At time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A slides to the right along a horizontal surface toward identical block B, which is at rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, block A collides elastically with block B and block A comes to rest. At time <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the right side of block B reaches an ideal, horizontal spring with negligible mass and spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The spring is initially at its relaxed (uncompressed) length and fixed to a wall. At time <math alttext="t sub 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the spring is compressed a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and block B is instantaneously at rest. Assume there is negligible friction between each block and the surface. For parts (a)-(d), consider the system consisting of block A, block B, and the spring. (a) Indicate whether the linear momentum of the two-block–spring system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to immediately before <math alttext="t sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(b) Indicate whether the mechanical energy of the two-block–spring system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to immediately before <math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(c) Indicate whether the linear momentum of the two-block–spring system is either constant or not constant during the time interval <math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

(d) Indicate whether the mechanical energy of the two-block–spring system is either constant or not constant during the time interval from <math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why.

In Case 2 shown above, the setup is identical to Case 1 except that the speed of block A before colliding with block B is greater than in Case 1. Block A again comes to rest immediately after colliding with block B. The spring compresses a maximum distance <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (e) How does the new maximum spring compression <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> compare to <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the spring compression in Case 1? (Is <math alttext="d sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the same as <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, or less than <math alttext="d sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?)
(f) Briefly explain your reasoning for part (e).

Students attempt to determine a general equation for the maximum compression distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of a spring with spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Blocks A and B each have mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and block A has initial speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students come up with the following two equations. Equation 1: <math alttext="d equals, C sub 1, end sub, times the square root of, the fraction m over v times k, end fraction, end root" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math> Equation 2: <math alttext="d equals, C sub 2, end sub, times the square root of, the fraction m over k, end root, times v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> In the two equations, <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive constants with appropriate units. (g) Without algebraic manipulation of equations or deriving the correct equation, explain which equation better supports your explanation for the compression distance in part (f).

(h) The graph above shows the displacement of the blocks while block B is in contact with the spring. The solid line corresponds to either Case 1 or Case 2, while the dashed line corresponds to the other case. Does the dashed-line curve correspond to Case 1 (slower block A) or Case 2 (faster block A)? Explain your reasoning.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
